content.description: Each voter from a random sample of <math alttext="334" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>334</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> registered voters was asked their impression of two candidates running for the same national office. The table summarizes the responses.
content.question: Candidate A Candidate B Favorable <math alttext="138" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>138</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="200" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Unfavorable <math alttext="44" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>44</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="47" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>47</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> No opinion <math alttext="88" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>88</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="47" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>47</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Have not heard of <math alttext="64" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>64</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="40" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> Which of the following is the most appropriate method to use to estimate the proportion of all registered voters who have a favorable impression of Candidate A?

choices.label: A one-sample <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for estimating a sample proportion
A one-sample <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for estimating a population proportion
A matched-pairs <math alttext="t" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for estimating a mean difference
A two-sample <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for estimating a difference between sample proportions
A two-sample <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for estimating a difference between population proportions

content.answer: A one-sample <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-interval for estimating a population proportion

topic.text: 6.2: Constructing a Confidence Interval for a Population Proportion

skill.text: Skill 1.D: Identify an appropriate inference method for confidence intervals.
